verses.text: Do not argue with a powerful person, or you might fall into their hands.
verses.comment: Sirach begins with practical advice about not provoking those who have greater power, reflecting a wisdom tradition found throughout Proverbs.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with someone rich, lest they overpower you. For wealth has ruined many.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the danger of quarreling with the wealthy, who have influence and resources that can be used against you.

verses.text: Do not argue with someone who talks much; do not heap more wood on their fire.
verses.comment: Arguing with those who love disputes only stirs up more conflict, echoing wisdom themes from the Book of Proverbs.

verses.text: Do not mock someone who is repentant for sin; remember that all of us deserve punishment.
verses.comment: Encouraging compassion for the penitent, this verse reflects humility before God, a foundation for reconciliation and mercy (see the parable of the Prodigal Son, Luke 15:11–32).

verses.text: Do not spurn someone when they are old, for we too will grow old.
verses.comment: Honoring the aged is a recurring theme rooted in the wisdom literature and in the commandment to honor your father and mother (Exodus 20:12).

verses.text: Do not rejoice over someone's death; remember that we are all mortal.
verses.comment: This passage points to the universality of death and subtly hints at the doctrine of the final judgment and the hope of resurrection as revealed later in the New Testament (1 Cor. 15:12–26).

verses.text: Do not reject the story told by the wise, but reflect on their teachings; for you will learn wisdom from them.
verses.comment: Listening to and pondering the words of the wise is a practice modeled by seeking understanding from those who have walked with God.

verses.text: Do not disregard the traditions of the elders; they were established for a reason.
verses.comment: Respecting spiritual tradition points to the continuity of wisdom and faith across generations, subtly underlining the importance of apostolic succession and sacred tradition for understanding God's revelation.

verses.text: Do not argue with someone for their words; sometimes they may speak from bitter knowledge.
verses.comment: Recognizing that people's words may come from deep pain calls for patience and empathy, as Christ himself demonstrated compassion for those who suffered.

verses.text: Do not despise someone who turns to God; instead, learn from their humility.
verses.comment: This echoes Christ's teaching of the tax collector in Luke 18, reminding us that contrition opens the door to grace.

verses.text: Do not hold back from speaking in time of danger, for people may rely on your words.
verses.comment: God sometimes places us in moments where speaking up may save others, as in the story of Esther. True wisdom discerns the moment for speech and silence.

verses.text: Do not base judgment on rumors; do not fall into danger through careless words.
verses.comment: Gossip and rash judgment are condemned throughout Scripture. The call to careful speech is part of living out the love of neighbor.

verses.text: Do not associate with a violent person, lest you learn their ways and become ensnared yourself.
verses.comment: The company we keep can corrupt our morals. This echoes Paul's teaching in 1 Cor. 15:33.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with someone who is angry; do not walk with them through desolate places, for harm may come to you.
verses.comment: Sirach warns against the association with those whose anger might lead to recklessness and danger, reminding us that prudence is a virtue.

verses.text: Do not take counsel with fools, for they cannot give good advice.
verses.comment: Choosing wise counselors is essential to spiritual health; see James 1:5 for encouragement to ask God for wisdom.

verses.text: Do not keep secrets from someone who cannot keep them.
verses.comment: Trust must be wisely placed and, as Christ taught, our yes must be yes and our no, no (Matt. 5:37).

verses.text: Do not do evil, and evil will not overcome you.
verses.comment: The principle of repaying evil with good is affirmed by Jesus; resisting evil is a call to holiness and perseverance.

verses.text: Do not dishonor yourself before others, or your reputation will suffer.
verses.comment: The virtue of integrity preserves one's reputation and witness, vital for being a light to others (see Matt. 5:16).

verses.text: Do not sit at the table with many people, nor with them do not repeat all your words.
verses.comment: Prudence in speech and company guards against scandal and indiscretion. Even at table, careful words foster peace and understanding.
